Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Consortium at the 2015 International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is to support US-based Ph.D. students to attend one of the most prestigious conferences of the IEEE Robotics and Automation Society and a doctoral consortium to be held concurrently. The conference is the 2015 International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS), which will be in Hamburg Germany from September 28 to October 2, 2015, in Hamburg, Germany. At the conference, they will be able to attend presentations of technical papers, attend workshops and tutorials on the latest advances, visit booths in which robotics companies are displaying their latest products, and attend special events designed for young researchers.

This proposal focuses on expanding the US capacity to advance robotics science and technologies by increasing the number of US-based PhD students who will attend IROS and participate in career-advancing activities. As part of attending this high-quality international robotics conference, the doctoral consortium offers a collection of events designed to help young researchers achieve high-quality research results more quickly. An impact of this is that they will more quickly become contributing members of the international research community and the US technology generation engine. The main special events offered to young US-based researcher through the doctoral consortium are networking luncheons and a tutorial on how to properly review scientific papers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award was to fund US-based doctoral students to attend the 2015 IEEE/RSJ International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS 2015) and the doctoral consortium. IROS is one of two premier robotics conferences in the world. The students were provided the opportunities to present, discuss, and receive feedback on original research and foster meaningful exchanges with highly experienced researchers in the broader international research community at the IROS 2015 conference. They also benefited from the doctoral consortium and related educational activities, including the discussion of the young reviewers program, the student Lunch with the Leaders, and the Women in Engineering lunch.

35 US-based doctoral students from 22 US universities were funded with this award and attended IROS 2015 and the doctoral consortium. They all presented their research and participated in the activities as mentioned above. The award made the trips of those students possible, and they all felt grateful for the valuable experience and benefits to their career development.

The young reviewers program has since launched by the IEEE Robotics and Automation Society. Many students actively participated in the program to be mentored in paper reviews for major robotics conferences, such as IROS 2016 and the 2017 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and  Automation.
